message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The tuberculin skin test (PPD) is a delayed-type hypersensitivity reaction mediated by T cells, particularly Th1 cells, and not by opsonization, complement activation, or IgE cross-linking. The skin test involves the injection of purified protein derivative (PPD) of Mycobacterium tuberculosis, and an area of induration at the site of injection is interpreted as a positive reaction indicating previous sensitization to the bacterium.

The PPD skin test is used to diagnose tuberculosis and measures the delayed-type hypersensitivity reaction, which is a Th1-mediated cytotoxicity response. A positive reaction indicates exposure to tuberculosis. Opsonization and complement activation are related to immune defense against bacterial and viral infections, and IgE cross-linking is related to allergic reactions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Tuberculin skin test (PPD) measures the delayed hypersensitivity response to mycobacterial antigens. The reaction involves the activation of CD4+ T-lymphocytes and release of cytokines, which lead to inflammation and erythema. This is a Th1-mediated cytotoxicity reaction. Opsonization, complement activation, and IgE cross-linking are not involved in this reaction.

Opsonization is the process of coating microorganisms with an opsonin to facilitate phagocytosis, complement activation is a part of immune system response to infection, and IgE cross-linking is involved in type 1 hypersensitivity reactions.

We refer to basic immunology principles for help. The tuberculin skin test measures a delayed-type hypersensitivity reaction, which is mediated by Th1 cells causing cytotoxicity to the antigen. Opsonization and complement activation are mechanisms of innate immunity and IgE cross-linking is involved in immediate hypersensitivity reactions, not delayed-type hypersensitivity.

Specifically, Th1 cells activate macrophages, leading to the release of cytokines and the recruitment of lymphocytes to the site of tuberculin injection. Option C is the only one related to T cell-mediated cytotoxicity. Opsonization involves the coating of pathogens with antibodies, complement activation involves a cascade of serum proteins that leads to inflammation and lysis of cells, and IgE cross-linking is involved in type 1 hypersensitivity reactions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The tuberculin skin test (PPD) involves the intradermal injection of a purified protein derivative of Mycobacterium tuberculosis. The resulting immune reaction is primarily mediated by Th1 cells, causing the formation of a raised, red induration at the site of injection. Opsonization, complement activation, and IgE cross-linking are not involved in this process.

Th1 cells and their production of cytokines such as interferon-gamma play a crucial role in the skin test reaction. Opsonization, complement activation, and IgE cross-linking are not involved in PPD skin test reactions.
